user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_bin_to_hex:
```c
size_t
MHD_bin_to_hex (const void *bin,
                size_t size,
                char *hex)
{
  size_t i;

  for (i = 0; i < size; ++i)
  {
    uint8_t j;
    const uint8_t b = ((const uint8_t *) bin)[i];
    j = b >> 4;
    hex[i * 2] = (char) ((j < 10) ? (j + '0') : (j - 10 + 'a'));
    j = b & 0x0f;
    hex[i * 2 + 1] = (char) ((j < 10) ? (j + '0') : (j - 10 + 'a'));
  }
  return i * 2;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the entire function control flow for any unreachable statements or blocks. The function has a single for-loop controlled by i from 0 to size (both size_t), with all statements inside the loop reachable whenever the loop executes; the body contains no early returns, goto, break that would render subsequent statements unreachable. If size is zero the loop body is simply not entered (intended behavior) and the final return i * 2 is reached — there is no code following that return to be unreachable. All assignments and ternary expressions in the loop depend on runtime values (b and its nibbles), so neither branch of the ternary operator is statically unreachable. No other functions, labels, or conditional compilation constructs are present that could introduce unreachable code. Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 (unreachable code).
